name: Mock Shaadi
description: Mock Shaadi is a large-scale cultural event celebrating the vibrant and intricate traditions of a South Asian wedding, offering students a unique and immersive experience. This event serves as a platform to showcase the diversity of South Asian customs, rituals, music, dance, in a festive and inclusive environment.

name: ACM Weekly Meeting
description: For Fall 2024, ACM will meet every Wednesday evening in Woodward 154 from 5:30 to 7:30. This 2-hour period is to accommodate more student availabilities. Please do not think of our meetings like classes. Students and prospective members should always feel free to drop in late or leave early as needed. During the first half of our meeting, we usually spend some time socializing and checking in with our peers, since networking is such an important professional skill to develop. For the rest of the time, we'll look at programming/coding problem together and split into pair programming groups to try and come up with solutions collaboratively. We will also set aside some time to discuss current topics and interests in tech and/or spend additional time workshopping resumes or interview skills with our peers.

description:

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Tuesday Volunteer Shift  |  10:30am – 12:45pm
description:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: Negotiating Your Employment Offer
description:
This workshop is eligible for the Niner Career Challenge!
Salary negotiation is often an afterthought in the job search process. Some people find it to be a nerve-racking and sweat-inducing proposition, but it doesn't have to be. With preparation, practice, and data-based dialogue, you can work to ensure that you are being paid a fair and equitable salary based on your education, experience, and unique qualifications. This workshop will put your mind at ease and provide the tools necessary to undertake the salary negotiation process. Register Here
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

description:

ASSP seeks to provide additional opportunities for students to learn more about their careers, and interact with safety professionals both on and off campus. These are our monthly (ish) meetings to discuss what's happening in the organization and help plan upcoming events. Some of these meetings may even have guest speakers from the industry!

name: Techstars Startup Weekend @Flywheel Coworking (Concord, NC)
description:
This is a community event. You will need to register on Eventbrite. Feel free to reach out to Laura Smailes (lsmailes@charlotte.edu) with any questions. The student ticket is $25.00. 
 
Want to get an immersion into the startup experience? Do you have an idea that you think might be able to develop into repeatable revenue? Do you have a passion to change the world? Then this weekend is for you!
From students to lifelong entrepreneurs, this is the perfect event for individuals of all ages looking to start a new business or learn more about the process of getting a startup off the ground.
Over an action-packed three days, you’ll meet the very best mentors, investors, co-founders, and sponsors to show you how to get more done faster -- and maybe even start that Business.
This is an in-person event at Flywheel Coworking in Concord, NC.
The weekend will be facilitated by a professional from Techstars and follow their proven formula for a 54-hour immersion in lean startup methods.
Parking is free and readily available. Ticketing includes all breakfasts, lunches, and dinners during the event. For overnight accommodation recommendations visit the event website at https://www.startupweekendconcord.com/
 
About Techstars: www.techstars.com
Techstars as an organization facilitates the acceleration of startups at a global scale with their pre-accelerator programming like Startup Weekends, their accelerators, and their investor network. Come join us and learn from the best!
 
Day 1 - Friday, November 8
5:30-10:30PM
Day 1 is all about welcoming participants to the event, making sure that everyone knows what will happen throughout the weekend, running the pitch fire, and facilitating team formation.
 
Day 2 - Saturday, November 9
8:30AM-9PM
Day 2 is all about getting things done. Participants work on their minimum viable product and receive mentorship from local industry experts.
 
Day 3 - Sunday, November 10
8:45AM-8PM
Day 3 is for completing work, final pitch presentations, networking, and celebrations! Valuable in-kind service awards of marketing, software development, and business development will be announced for 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place teams following the pitches.
 
Why Startup Weekend
Connect with other creators
Startup Weekend is a great place to connect with passionate people driven to build something new. There is no better place to meet new friends, colleagues, mentors, cofounders, and investors.
 
Start something great
Knowing you’re not alone can make all the difference. Startup Weekend provides participants many opportunities to engage and connect with like-minded individuals — and truly start something amazing.
 
Learn from the best
Learn what it really takes to innovate, disrupt, and start a company from people who’ve been there. Startup Weekend features deep experiential learning guided by an experienced hand.
 
Improve your knowledge
Sometimes you really need more skills and knowledge to go to the next level. Startup Weekend also goes deep on specific topics or skill sets. Just what you need to progress quickly.

name: MCPH Department Panel
description: Come and join us for the MCPH Department Panel on Monday, November 4th, from 6-7:30 pm in COED 065 in collaboration with GPHA! Three amazing guest speakers will join us on this panel: Aleah McKenney, a Program Coordinator for the Overdose Data to Action Division; Danielle Crawford, a Clinical Outreach Coordinator for the Overdose Data to Action Division; and Dr. Raynard Washington, the Director of the Mecklenburg County Public Health Department. Join us to hear from them as they dive into their journeys and share their insights and experiences for success in Public Health. This is your chance to connect and be inspired!

name: Career Meet Up: Behavioral Interviewing
description:
Behavioral-based interview questions are the most common interview questions employers ask. Discuss and practice how to successfully answer behavioral-based interview questions using the STAR method. Join our meet up and learn best practices in preparing for and effectively acing case interviews. Career Meet Ups are 30-45 minute small group sessions focused on specific topics and led by career coaches or industry professionals. Attending Career Meet Ups will also help you gain highly useful career skills that are valuable to all employers; learn more at career.charlotte.edu/careerskills. Meet Ups may be virtual or in-person, and you will have the opportunity to gain information, ask questions, and get some practice. If you need accommodations to access this Meet Up, contact Brandi Ledermann, Meet Up Program Manager, at blederma@charlotte.edu or 704-687- 0791.
Join this link.
To earn the credit for this virtual workshop, you must complete this form.
This workshop counts towards the Career Development PILOT credit.

name: Truist Immersive Learning Event Information Session
description:
Calling ALL majors!Are you ready to take your career to new heights? Then mark your calendars for the highly anticipated Truist Immersive Learning Event happening on Friday, March 28th, and Saturday, March 29th in the Truist Innovation and Technology Center in Uptown Charlotte. This is an incredible opportunity that you won't want to miss!
Truist professionals will be visiting our campus on Monday, November 4th, for an exclusive information session for the Immersive Event. Not only will you get a sneak peek into what the event has in store, but you'll also have the chance to network with professionals at Truist. You don't want to miss out!
To secure your spot and maximize your chance to be a part of this immersive experience, we strongly urge you to attend the information session on November 4th. Join us on campus at the Info Session, where UNC Charlotte faculty and Truist professionals will provide you with all the necessary information, logistics, and expectations for the event. 
This is your chance to gain hands-on knowledge, build meaningful connections, and propel your career forward. Don't let this incredible opportunity pass you by - be sure to attend the information session on November 4th. Check out our recap videos. 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LO52TxnkVmw
https://youtu.be/bAEClB2gV9A
host: Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation, Truist Institute for Student Success

name: Navigating Your Pharmacy Future: Insights & Opportunities Seminar with MUSC
description:
Join Us for an Informative Pharmacy Seminar! 










Are you interested in a career in pharmacy? Curious about the different paths you can take in this diverse field? Don't miss our upcoming seminar, where we'll cover key topics to help you navigate your journey:
- Career Options in Pharmacy: Explore roles in hospital, clinical, research, and more!
- Pharmacy School Application Process: Get tips on how to successfully apply.
- PharmD Curriculum Insights: Learn about the coursework and expectations in a PharmD program.
- The Evolving Pharmacy Profession: Stay updated on the latest trends and opportunities.




Whether you're just starting or well on your way, this seminar is for you! This event is open to all Pre-Health students, or anyone interested in a career in pharmacy!

name: Procrastination Workshop Series
location: Visualization Lab, J. Murrey Atkins Library, 2nd floor
description:
Struggling with procrastination? One part of you knows what you should be doing, and another part of you still puts it off until the last minute or doesn't do it at all, so you're left feeling panicked, guilty, or frustrated with yourself. Join us for a workshop addressing common causes of procrastination, including perfectionism and external pressures. We will explore the thoughts, behaviors, and emotions that often prevent us from being as productive and on-task as we would like. We will discuss practical tools to improve time management and accountability, along with ways to reframe your mindset and manage the emotions that come up with procrastination. 
 
This is a 3 part workshop happening on 3 consecutive Wednesdays. To receive the most benefits, please plan to attend all 3 workshop. Sign up for the other two session:
October 16, 4-5pm
October 23, 4-5pm
host: Counseling and Psychological Services, J. Murrey Atkins Library

name: CEO of 11Sight - Speaker Series
description: We’re excited to welcome the CEO of 11Sight for our next Speaker Series event! 11Sight, a cutting-edge video communication platform, has transformed the way businesses engage with customers. The CEO will share their entrepreneurial journey, insights on building a tech company from the ground up, and the vital role of sales in driving innovation and growth. This is a fantastic opportunity to learn about leadership, the future of sales technology, and how to leverage digital tools for success. Don’t miss the chance to interact with an industry leader and gain inspiration for your own career path!

name: Mario Kart 6th Floor Game Night

Join us for an epic Mario Kart Game Night! Whether you're a seasoned racer or a first-time player, everyone is welcome to put their skills to the test in this fast-paced, fun-filled gaming event. Compete against your neighbors, enjoy friendly competition, and race your way to victory. We'll provide snacks, drinks, and prizes for the top finishers. Don’t miss out on a night of laughter, excitement, and thrilling races on the track. Controllers in hand, let’s see who will be crowned the ultimate Mario Kart champion! WAHOO!

name: Welding Day
description: The ASCE Steel Bridge Welding Day is an event designed to introduce students to basic welding methods and processes commonly used in steel fabrication. The primary goal is to give participants hands-on experience with MIG welding, which is used in constructing the steel bridge for competition. Students will learn safety procedures and be equipped with personal protective equipment while observing and participating in the welding process. The event aims to foster interest in the Steel Bridge Team by showing students a key aspect of bridge fabrication.

name: Jamil Niner Student Pantry: Thursday Volunteer Shift  |  2:30pm – 5:15pm
description:
The Jamil Niner Student Pantry assists UNC Charlotte students and faculty/staff who are having challenges accessing food regularly. Through volunteering, you will be working with the pantry leadership team to provide healthy, culturally appropriate, and emergency foods to students, faculty, and staff on campus. Volunteer activities may include, but are not limited to: checking shoppers in and out, assisting with pantry upkeep, stocking and sorting food, garden work, and other various activities to help run the pantry. Please wear closed-toed shoes and comfortable clothing when volunteering at the food pantry. Enter through the front door and proceed to the conference room for volunteer check-in. 
If you are unable to stay for the duration of the volunteer shift, please notify a team member before leaving your shift. 
Questions? Email ninerpantry@charlotte.edu.

name: Free HIV/STI Testing
description: The Center for Wellness Promotion and Student Health are collaborating with community partners to provide free HIV/STI testing to Charlotte students. name: Fireside Chat with Industry Professionals
description:
Join us for an engaging and insightful evening at the Fireside Chat with Industry Professionals. This informal and interactive event will provide students with the unique opportunity to hear from accomplished professionals in the engineering industry. Through an open Q&A session and panel discussion, industry leaders will share their experiences, career paths, and insights on emerging trends in engineering.
 
Attendees will gain valuable knowledge about navigating their careers, networking, and how to succeed in a rapidly evolving field. This is a perfect chance to ask questions, seek advice, and learn more about what it takes to thrive in the engineering profession.
 
Event Highlights:

Interactive Q&A with industry professionals
Networking opportunities with experts and peers
Free dinner for all attendees
Exciting door prizes
Insightful discussions on career growth, industry trends, and challenges

 
Whether you're a seasoned ASME member or new to the field, this event is designed to inspire and inform the next generation of engineers.
 
Ticket Cost:Tickets are available for $3. This fee includes entry into the event with all benefits.
 
Registration:To attend the event, please register through Eventbrite using the link below. Secure your spot today!
 
https://asme-fireside-chat.eventbrite.com/
host: American Society of Mechanical Engineers at UNC Charlotte

name: Office of Undergraduate Research Drop-In Hours
description:
Have questions about undergraduate research?  What is it?  Why should I do research?  How will it help me in my classes or getting hired after graduation?  How do I get involved?  How do I find opportunities? How do I apply?  What does a good application look like?  How do I make my resume reflect my research experiences?  How do I attend conferences and present my research?  
The Office of Undergraduate Research (OUR) can answer all these questions and many more.  Just drop in for open hours every Monday or Wednesday afternoon and we can help.

name: Holiday Hero's (Youth Villages)
description:
Youth Villages is a national leader in children’s mental and behavioral health focused on providing the most effective help to children with emotional and behavioral problems, their families and young adults who are aging out of state services. By partnering with innovative state leaders and philanthropists, Youth Villages spurs positive change to child welfare, children’s mental health and juvenile justice systems through public-private partnerships, value or performance-based contracting. Youth Villages focuses on achieving long-lasting positive outcomes for the most challenging youth and families. 
- At this event you will be wrapping gifts to be sent to low income families that may not have any Christmas gifts.

name: Student Org Toolbox Series
description:
This week's topic: Building Your Social Media Presence 
 
Unlock your student organization's full potential with the Student Org Toolbox Series! Join us bi-weekly for dynamic sessions designed to equip your group with the skills, strategies, and resources needed for success. Each event covers a wide range of topics and features various interactive formats, including engaging dialogues, hands-on activities, opportunities for collaboration, and guest presentations from various folks and departments across campus. Whether you're looking to improve your leadership, boost member engagement, or enhance your group's impact, the Toolbox Series has something for everyone. Don't miss out on these valuable opportunities to learn, grow, and connect!

name: IEW: International Karaoke Night
description:
Join us Wednesday, November 20th 6:00pm - 8:00PM in the McKnight hall in Cone!
To celebrate International Education Week, the Study Abroad Ambassadors from the Office of Education Abroad are hosting International Karaoke. This is a night to appreciate different cultures through song.Dive into a world of music and culture at our International Karaoke event! Whether you’re a seasoned performer or just looking to have some fun, this is your chance to shine. Sing your heart out with songs from around the globe, discover new genres, and connect with fellow music lovers.
Get ready for an unforgettable night filled with laughter, friendship, and incredible performances. Come share your voice, embrace the rhythm, and celebrate the diversity of global music. Don't miss out—let's make some memories together! 🎶✨
Check out other IEW events happening in the OGEE Calendar!

name: Ballin on a Budget
description:
Join Niner Finances for Ballin on a Budget. 
Budgeting is often misunderstood as a restrictive and joyless task, but in reality, it's a tool for financial empowerment and fulfillment. By creating a budget aligned with your means, you can plan spending effectively and enjoy life. Consistent budgeting enables you to achieve financial goals while managing daily responsibilities. Through self-assessment, goal setting, commitment, and basic math, budgeting becomes the cornerstone of financial success.

name: Game Jam
location: Area 49 Visualization Lab, Atkins Library, room 244.
description:
Do you want to make a game for Area 49's brand new game cabinet? Join us for our Game Jam kickoff with Zach Pulliam, owner of Super Abari Game Bar and Ammar Ahmed, maker of Crab Volleyball, as they give participants the guidelines for how to create a game for the arcade cabinet. Your team’s game could be played on Area 49’s game cabinets housed in both Area 49’s Gaming Lab and in Super Abari!
 
This will be a two-part, in-person event in Area 49’s Visualization Lab, Atkins Library, room 244.
Kickoff: October 16, 2-3pm
Game Showing & Judging: November 13, 2-4pm 
 
Teams of 2-5 will have one month to complete their games using Godot Engine. If you don’t have a team yet or you’re not sure of your skills, not to worry! We’ll find the right team for you. All students may join regardless of skill level, major, or type of contribution, and great games need coders, storytellers, artists, and more!
 
For more details, visit our page bit.ly/Area49Abari.
For questions, contact atkinsarea49@charlotte.edu.
Please fill out the Registration Form and plan to attend both the Kickoff and the Judging/Showing. We'll see you there!

name: Campfire & Cave Exploration
description:
Join Venture Outdoor Leadership for a caving adventure like no other! We will drive out to the caving area on Saturday, camping nearby. Sunday morning will be spent exploring Worley's cave as a group. This is a great cave for those new to caving as there are paths to opt-out of the tight squeezes. Your adventure trip leaders will teach you about camping, caving, ecology, cave preservation, and more throughout this overnight experience. 
The Bristol, TN area is the traditional home of the Eastern Band of Cherokee and the S'atsoyaha (Yuchi) (source: native-land.ca)
Costs include: Transportation to/from campus; meals; equipment; technical clothing (e.g. rain jackets); instruction. 

Student - $95
Faculty/Staff/Alumni - $110
Community - $150

Mandatory Pre-Trip Meeting: Wed, Nov. 13, 5:30pm
Registration due by Wed, Nov. 13, 12pm.

name: Completing an IRB Protocol Application
description:
This workshop is eligible for the Niner Career Challenge!
Preparing an IRB proposal/application may be intimidating as a student researcher.  You may not know how much detail to provide in your application or what documents the IRB requires you to provide.   In this workshop, you will hear from UNC Charlotte's IRB office to learn about the IRB application process.  Including tips for preparing an IRB application and mistakes to avoid.  Because this workshop is intended to give a detailed review of the IRB application and help guide you for preparing your own IRB application, this workshop would be ideal for students who will be starting their IRB applications this academic year.  Attendees should be prepared to talk about their own study plans.Instructor: Cat RundenRegister here!

name: Procrastination Workshop Series
location: Visualization Lab, J. Murrey Atkins Library, 2nd floor
description:
Struggling with procrastination? One part of you knows what you should be doing, and another part of you still puts it off until the last minute or doesn't do it at all, so you're left feeling panicked, guilty, or frustrated with yourself. Join us for a workshop addressing common causes of procrastination, including perfectionism and external pressures. We will explore the thoughts, behaviors, and emotions that often prevent us from being as productive and on-task as we would like. We will discuss practical tools to improve time management and accountability, along with ways to reframe your mindset and manage the emotions that come up with procrastination.
 
This is a 3 part workshop happening on 3 consecutive Wednesdays. To receive the most benefits, please plan to attend all 3 workshop. Sign up for the other two session:
November 13, 4-5pm
November 20, 4-5pm

name: Meet the Math Faculty!
description:
The event aims to create a relaxed environment where mathematics students and faculty can connect and engage. While open to all, it is specifically designed for students taking math courses to meet and interact with the department. Attendees can enjoy games, pizza, and a chance to foster stronger relationships and understanding between students and mentors. We hope to encourage a casual, welcoming atmosphere and invite everyone to join.


This event will foster meaningful connections between students and faculty at UNC Charlotte, creating a supportive environment for those who may find math classes intimidating. By engaging directly with math faculty, students will see that math is not something to fear, and that the professors are approachable and invested in their success. The event offers a space for students to explore the vast opportunities available in mathematics, including research and career paths, helping them realize their potential and feel a sense of belonging within both the math department and the broader UNC Charlotte community. With 17 faculty members confirmed and more showing interest, the event will strengthen the bonds that make our community inclusive and academically enriching.

name: Innovation Barn
description:
The Innovation Barn, the city’s center for circular innovation, is one of the busiestplaces in the city. Its restaurant serves food from its greenhouse and garden, and itscircular stores have a wide variety of upcycled products on offer. It is also a center forexperimentation and education, home to specialized repair facilities and workshopson sustainable design and the potential of waste. New ideas, ranging from 3D printedplastic building bricks to leather made from fruit peels, are piloted at The Barn, and thenscaled up in many other parts of the city. The Barn has also led to a completely differentsocial dynamic than existed in the 2010s, when the main options for spending time withfriends included drinking at a café or bar. People from all corners of the city come to theBarn to learn new skills, but also to socialize while repairing their own clothes or tradingtheir old furniture for something new.
-Transportation is provided

name: Volunteer Opportunity | Landscaping at McCreesh Place
description:
Volunteer Event Details:

Activity: Landscaping at McCreesh Place
Date & Time: November 15th, 10:00 AM – 12:00 PM
Location: 2120 N. Davidson Street, Charlotte, NC 28205
Parking: Onsite parking available. Convenient access via the Blue Line light rail stop just a block away!

Volunteer Opportunity at McCreesh Place: Landscaping Event
Join us for a rewarding volunteer experience at McCreesh Place, Charlotte’s first permanent supportive housing complex, located in the Villa Heights community. Opened in 2003, McCreesh Place offers 64 Single Room Occupancy units with shared bathrooms and kitchens, along with 26 one-bedroom units. These homes serve chronically homeless individuals in active recovery from addiction. Our case managers provide supportive services to help residents reach personal goals related to finances, employment, relationships, health, and recovery.
McCreesh Place is a Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH) facility—a best-practice, cost-effective model designed to address chronic homelessness. Studies show that individuals in PSH are less likely to return to homelessness within two years compared to those in other programs, making this a life-changing solution.
Your efforts will make a direct impact on this community. No experience is required, just bring your enthusiasm to help beautify the space and support the residents of McCreesh Place. We look forward to working alongside you!

name: Book Talk with Local Author Vanessa Miller "The American Queen"
description:
Vanessa Miller is a best-selling, award-winning author, playwright, and motivational speaker. Her writing has been centered on themes of redemption, often focusing on characters facing multi-dimensional struggles.
Several of Vanessa’s novels have appeared on Essence Magazine’s Bestseller’s List. She has also been a #1 Amazon Bestseller. Miller’s work has receiving numerous awards, including the 2024 American Fiction Award winner for Historical Fiction, and the 2022 Best Christian Fiction award for her novel, "Something Good," at the African American Literary Awards Show.
Vanessa’s books have received countless favorable reviews. The American Queen has been featured in GMA, Washington Post and Essence Magazine roundups. Vanessa lives in North Carolina with her husband and family. She graduated from Capital University with a degree in Organizational Communication.

name: Finding Your Voice in STEM Writing
description:
Join science journalist Eleanor Cummins for an interactive one-hour workshop designed to identify your unique STEM writing voice. This session will introduce participants to the fundamental principles of crafting compelling and effective STEM stories. In a guided exercise with an experienced science journalist, students will explore how to develop and refine their distinctive writing voice, and apply it to headline-making material. The workshop will also cover various popular story structures, including op-eds, feature articles, explainers, and more, providing participants with the tools to bridge their signature style with the needs of their audience.
 
Register Here
 
About Eleanor Cummins:
 


Her work has appeared in more than 30 national outlets, including The Atlantic, The New York Times, and National Geographic.


In 2017, she graduated from New York University's Science, Health, and Environmental Reporting Program, where she served as an adjunct assistant professor from 2020 to 2024. 
 
Eleanor received a 2018 Edible Award for her reporting on New York City oysters; a 2022 Azbee Award for her profile of Dr. Will Flanary; and a 2023 National City and Regional Magazine Award for her “masterful examination” of allegations against a Texas funeral home.
 
Her reporting on OCD received a notable mention in the Best American Science and Nature Writing 2022. 
 
Her essay on climate change in the Pokémon franchise will be anthologized in the forthcoming book Pokemon & Philosophy, out November 2024.

name: Effective Academic Presentations
description:
This workshop is eligible for the Niner Career Challenge!
At some point as a graduate student and in your career, you'll likely need to speak in front of professors, academic colleagues or at professional academic conferences. Yikes! Just thinking about public speaking—routinely described as one of the greatest (and most common) fears—can make your palms sweat. But there are many ways to tackle this anxiety and learn to deliver a memorable presentation.
 
Speaking in front of people is a skill, not an innate ability. In this workshop, you will learn the seven-steps to prepare and improve your public speaking and presentation skills and engage an academic audience. Come and learn how to step in front of your audience with your best foot forward.
Register Here
 
Presenter: Dr. Daryl L. Kerr, Adjunct Professor and former Professor of Management and Business Communication, Belk College of Business
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: What Do I Do with My Hands? Nonverbal Communication in Presentations
description:
This workshop is eligible for the Niner Career Challenge!
Every gesture, from the movement of your hands to eye contact, will send different signals to the audience about your capabilities and understanding of the subject. Nonverbal communications are the most challenging aspect for people to improve when public speaking. In this workshop, we will discuss the most important nonverbal tips for public speaking.
This information will significantly assist you in communication because nonverbal communication and verbal communication are the two core components of public speaking. While verbal communication can be improved with extensive practice, nonverbal communication directly impacts the audience’s ability to comprehend the message. Imagine, if you see a public speaker who delivers their point coherently and comprehensively, what will you think if they keep looking down or sideways, and put their hands behind their back? Between verbal and non-verbal communication, it’s the latter who speaks louder. Think about it. By paying close attention to your nonverbal communication, you can improve the delivery of your message.
 
Register Here
 
Presenter: Dr. Daryl L. Kerr, Adjunct Professor and former Professor of Management and Business Communication, Belk College of Business
host: The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: Networking Across Cultures
description:
This workshop is eligible for the 2024 Niner Career Challenge!
Most people feel a little intimidated about networking, and this is especially true when you are new to a culture. Are you familiar with the saying, "it's not what you know, it's who you know"? In the US, connections with people carry a lot of weight when looking for a job. This is why networking is a fundamental skill for launching and furthering your career. However, when we hear the word "networking," we often think of "doing lunch," selling ourselves, and handing out business cards. If we changed the word to “connecting,” we might feel better about it. Your job search begins with the people you know! Never underestimate their knowledge and influence. Most people are enthusiastic about connecting and see it as mutually beneficial.
Elona Ellis serves as the Assistant Director for the Peer Professionals and Career Coach for the Technology, Data and Analytics career community
Register here

name: Instructor of Record Training II- Combining Critical Thinking & Assessment
description:
This workshop is eligible for the Niner Career Challenge!
When IORs teach new material, design activities, and create assessments, it is helpful for them to consider at what level of thinking they want their students to operate.  Mindful use of the critical thinking model can assist with these goals.  The critical thinking model also works well with models of memory, so that long-term understanding of material occurs.  This workshop will present an overview of those models to help IORs design effective teaching and testing practices.

description:
The Charlotte Recovery Program (CRP) offers the Real Talk Recovery: Recovery Ally training. As a Recovery Ally, you can play a vital role in normalizing recovery support on and off campus. This training is apart of the H.E.L.P certificate. 
Recovery Ally training equips you to:

Explore the different substances linked to substance misuse and addiction.
Recognize signs, risk factors, and symptoms of someone experiencing substance misuse.
Identify various pathways to recovery from substance misuse and addiction.
Discover resources that students experiencing substance misuse can utilize to receive support.
Acquaint yourself with on-campus and off-campus resources.
Provide tips and ideas to create a substance-free space for yourself and your friends to have fun.

name: Waterway Getaway - Canoe Camping
description:
Join Venture Outdoor Leadership for this canoe camping trip!  We'll explore Lake James State Park in canoes, following the shoreline while enjoying the views, learning how to work together as a team, and honing the craftsmanship of tandem canoes.  Designed for both beginners and experienced canoeists, our adventure trip leaders will guide and teach along the way.
While no experience is necessary, comfort being submerged in water is required. While we don't plan on capsizes, they may happen. The pre-trip meeting will include a water-comfort assessment in the Belk Gym pool. 
If you have any questions or concerns, please reach out to our office at venturedept@charlotte.edu
Exact location will be based on weather and river levels. 
Costs include: Transportation to/from campus; meals; equipment; technical clothing (e.g. rain jackets); instruction. 

Student - $95
Faculty/Staff/Alumni - $110
Community - $150

Mandatory Pre-Trip Meeting: Wed, Nov. 6, 5:30pm
Registration due by Wed, Nov. 6, 12pm.

description:

name: Procrastination Workshop Series
location: Visualization Lab, J. Murrey Atkins Library, 2nd floor
description:
Struggling with procrastination? One part of you knows what you should be doing, and another part of you still puts it off until the last minute or doesn't do it at all, so you're left feeling panicked, guilty, or frustrated with yourself. Join us for a workshop addressing common causes of procrastination, including perfectionism and external pressures. We will explore the thoughts, behaviors, and emotions that often prevent us from being as productive and on-task as we would like. We will discuss practical tools to improve time management and accountability, along with ways to reframe your mindset and manage the emotions that come up with procrastination.
 
This is a 3 part workshop happening on 3 consecutive Wednesdays. To receive the most benefits, please plan to attend all 3 workshop. Sign up for the other two session:
November 6, 4-5pm 
November 13, 4-5pm

name: Your Choices Matter: Academic Publishing Survival Guide
description:
The challenges in academic publishing begin well before the first word hits the page - every grad student knows that. But what many don’t know is that there is a wealth of tools and tips that make the process not only easier, but more fulfilling. Garrison Libby and Jeff McAdams, experts from the Atkins Library, lead this virtual workshop overview of academic publishing - and, more importantly, your agency within it. Learn how to find the right journals for you, get the rundown on open access publishing, and more - there will even be time for a Q&A session at the end. This Survival Guide will show you concrete ways to take control of your research and decide how you put it out into the world.
 
Questions? Contact Garrison Libby (g.libby@charlotte.edu) or Jeff McAdams (jmmcadams@charlotte.edu) in Atkins Library!
 

Please register here and we will send you a calendar invite with a Zoom link.
host: J. Murrey Atkins Library, The Center for Graduate Life and Learning

name: BITS en Bleu
description:
Join us for an unforgettable evening of elegance and opportunity at BITS en Bleu, a formal networking dinner designed to connect students with professionals in business and technology fields. This event offers a chance to build valuable connections while enjoying a sophisticated dinner in a business-formal setting. With a blue color theme, attendees are encouraged to embrace the spirit of the evening by incorporating blue into their formal attire. Whether you're an aspiring business leader, a tech enthusiast, or simply looking to expand your professional network, BITS en Bleu provides the perfect atmosphere to engage with industry professionals and fellow students in a relaxed yet refined setting.
Dress Code: Business Formal (Blue Theme)

name: Niners for Social Impact Interest Meeting
description: Come learn about our new student organization, Niners for Social Impact! We will be introducing the Executive Board, talking about our mission and goals, future events, and ways to get involved. Everyone is welcome! Join other like-minded students, learn what Niners for Social Impact is all about, and get ready to turn your ideas into impact!
